III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Last month, Youth became ill and was taken to the hospital a
week later. Youth was not taken to the hospital until staff were
threatened with a CPS complaint. Youth had a potentially fatal
diagnosis if left untreated. After discharge from the hospital, Staff
2 did not comply with youth's follow-up appointment.
Investigation This complaint was received on 03/10/2023 and investigated in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist.
The complainant was anonymous, and no contact information was
received for follow-up.
I interviewed Consumer Rights Officer on 03/10/2023. He reported
Youth B was ill last month and was initially taken to Urgent Care
and a few days later taken to Children’s Hospital. He said Youth B
was diagnosed with UTI and Thrush. Consumer Rights Officer
reported he is not aware of any concerns regarding staff not
complying with youth’s follow up care. He said Staff 2 is a lead
worker and does not work directly with Youth B.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility on 03/10/2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Specialist 1. Youth B reported feeling safe and getting
enough to eat. Youth B is developmental delayed, but kept saying
after every question, “that’s it”, and asked if she can leave. Youth
B was observed to be well and healthy.
A second interview was attempted of Youth B at the facility on
03/13/2023, in collaboration with DHHS Specialist 2. Youth B was
asked if she recalled being sick and going to the hospital, Youth B
said she did not want to talk, and walked out of the room back to
the unit.
I interviewed Nurse 1 at the facility on 03/10/2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Specialist 2. Nurse 1 recalled that Youth B was sick
last month and was taken to urgent care and then to the hospital
due to high fever. She examined Youth B in the morning on
2

02/01/2023 Youth B had a temperature of 100 degrees and was
given Tylenol and responded well to it. She evaluated Youth B
later in the day and Youth B’s temperature went up to 102
degrees. Nurse 1 contacted the doctor, the doctor told her to give
Youth B Tylenol, a lot of fluids, and to continue to monitor her
fever. The doctor did a follow up exam, tested for COVID
(negative) and said it was viral and to continue to monitor and give
her a lot of fluids. She said Youth B was not eating much, but she
was drinking fluids. Nurse 1 reported on 02/02/2023 the doctor
examined Youth B and recommended she be taken to urgent care
due her continuing to have a fever. Youth B was diagnosed with
Strep Throat, was constipated, so she was given a Penicillin shot
and Miralax. Nurse 1 continued to follow up daily on Youth B and
was informed that Youth B’s throat was feeling better, but Youth B
was complaining of stomach cramps. Nurse 1 said she reached
out to the doctor and was told the penicillin shot needs a few days
to be effective. She said on 02/06/2023 she checked up on Youth
B and Youth B was still not feeling well, so she was taken to
Children’s Hospital. Youth B was diagnosed with a UTI and
Thrush. She said Youth B did have a follow up with the facility’s
doctor after she was discharged.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 03/13/2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Specialist 2. Staff 1 has been working at the facility for
13 years and is a first shift supervisor. She recalls Youth B being
sick and not having an appetite, but said Youth B was seen by the
nurse, doctor, and was taken to the urgent care. She said Youth B
was also on her cycle and she was complaining about having
stomach cramps. She didn’t work the weekend that Youth B was
sick, but when she came into work on 02/06/2023 Youth B had
already been taken to Children’s Hospital. She said Youth B was
diagnosed with UTI and Thrush and when she was discharged
from the hospital Youth B was seen by the facility doctor. She is
not aware of Youth B having any issues or concerns with any staff
member. Staff 1 said the facility’s policy is when a Youth is ill staff
are to notify the nurse and doctor.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility on 03/13/2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Specialist 2. Staff 2 is a Lead Worker and has been
working at the facility for 6 years. She reported Youth B was seen
by the nurse, doctor, and taken to the urgent care the week she
was sick. Staff 2 said Youth B was diagnosed with Strep, UTI, and
Thrush. She said Youth B is on 1:1 and staff were in regular
contact with the nurse and Youth B was seen by the facility’s
doctor after she was discharged from the hospital. She denied
minimizing or not following up on Youth B when she was ill. Staff 2
3

reported she has a good relationship with Youth B and said that
Youth B sometimes refers her as “mom”, even though she tries to
discourage Youth B from referring to her as “mom”.
I interviewed Staff 3 at the facility on 03/13/2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Specialist 2. Staff 3 is a direct care worker and is
usually the one assigned to work with Youth B, because Youth B
is on 1:1. She was assigned to Youth B on 02/06/2023. She said
on 02/06/2023 Youth B was still not feeling well and was informed
that they had to take Youth B to Children’s Hospital. She and
another staff member transported Youth B to Children’s Hospital.
Staff 3 said Youth B had a bad case of Thrush and was not eating
well but was drinking fluids. She said Youth B was complaining of
stomach cramps. She said staff did follow the facility’s protocol
when a youth is sick, which is to notify the team lead, or the
supervisor and they will contact the nurse. She said staff and team
leaders followed up with the nurse and provided updates on Youth
B when she was ill. She expressed no concerns regarding Staff 2
not complying and following up when Youth B was ill.
I interviewed Youth B’s Foster Care Specialist via telephone on
03/15/2023. Foster Care Specialist reported Youth B is on a 1:1
supervision. She was notified last month when Youth B was ill and
had a visit with Youth B on 02/06/2023 before Youth B was taken
to the hospital. She expressed no concerns regarding the facility
or staff ensuring Youth B was receiving medical care when she
was ill. She said Youth B was examined by the nurse and doctor
at the facility, taken to urgent care, and then to the hospital. She
said staff were monitoring Youth B closely and in regular contact
with the nurse. She said Youth B has been at the facility for almost
five years and she has never had any concerns regarding the
facility providing care and supervision.
A predisposition conference call held with DHHS Specialist 2 on
04/04/2023 and resulted in no findings.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
• Facility Medical Complaints Policy: If a client becomes
seriously ill or is injured, the shift Supervisor and or Team
Leader must take prompt steps to obtain medical care for
the client.
• Nurse assessment dated 02/01/2023 at 10 am for Youth B.
Youth B was seen for abdominal pain. Youth’s temperature
100.0, Youth was given Tylenol. Youth was reassessed at
11 am and Youth reported feeling better, will continue to
monitor.
4

• Nurse assessment dated 02/01/2023 at 4:05 pm. Youth B
temperature 102. A Covid test was completed, doctor
contact, recommend Tylenol and keeping youth hydrated,
and doctor will see youth in the clinic the following day.
• Doctor exam dated 02/02/2023 at 2:00 pm. Youth B was
examined for fatigue and fever symptoms consistent with
viral illness. If Youth stops drinking and fever continues will
recommend evaluated in the emergency department.
• Nurse assessment dated 02/03/2023 at 4:45 pm. Youth B
temperature was 100.1, no appetite, and lethargic.
• Henry Ford Urgent Care medical record for Youth B dated
02/03/2023. Youth B was examined and diagnosed with
Strep and constipation.
• Medical Record from Children’s Hospital for Youth B dated
02/06/2023. Youth B was admitted on 02/06/2023 and
discharged on 02/07/2023. Youth B was treated for UTI and
thrush. General physical exam Youth B was alert and
oriented, well-nourished, and well developed. Discharge
plans follow up with PCP within one week.
• Doctor exam dated 02/13/2023 at 2:00pm for Youth B for
hospital discharge follow up. Youth B temperature 98.6,
improved appetite, no pain, and having daily bowel
movements.
Analysis The facility is not in violation as the documentation provided by the
facility and interviews with Staff, Nurse, and Youth B, confirmed
Youth B was provided the medical care required when she was ill.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was hoarding pills in their room and staff were not
appropriately monitoring this.
Investigation Youth B reported she takes medication and gets her medication
daily. She said staff give her medication and check her mouth to
make sure she swallowed the medication. She denied hiding the
medication in her mouth.
5

Consumer Rights officer reported Youth B had no incident reports
in reference to her “cheeking” or not taking her medication.
Nurse 1 reported there is no history for Youth B hoarding pills or
not taking her medication.
Staff 1 denied any concern regarding Youth B hoarding pills. She
reported Youth B is on 1:1 and there are no incident reports
regarding Youth B cheeking her medication.
Staff 2 reported hoarding medication has never been an issue for
Youth B. She said they complete daily rooms checks and there
has never been any concerns for Youth B hoarding or “cheeking”
her medication. Staff 2 said the medicine process is that the youth
come to the medication room one at a time, the medication is
scanned, and the youth is given their medication. Youth take their
medication and they open their mouths to ensure they have
swallowed the medication.
Foster Care Specialist reported no concerns regarding Youth B
hoarding or not taking her medication.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
• Reviewed medication administration policy: Staff
dispensing medication are to carefully watch the client take
oral medication and verify all medications have been
swallowed by checking the mouth for any retained
medication.
Analysis There is insufficient evidence that Youth B was hoarding her
medication based on interviews with Staff, Nurse, and Youth B.
Youth B and Staff confirmed staff dispensed medication according
to their policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
